CatDescriptText: Preston Brooks, postal worker, 1600 Saturn Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 6, 1959, pg. 1 with question: "Do you think that racial prejudice is inherent or is it taught to children? If you believe that it is taught do you think that the teaching of it is increasing or diminishing?  If so, by whom do you think that it is taught?" answer reads: "Racial prejudice in children, in my opinion, is taught rather than inherited.  I think that it's taught by the parents and I think that perhaps it is increasing because of the trouble concerning school integration in the South."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Preston Brooks wearing light colored striped button down collared shirt, cap, and moustache, standing in front of three story building, street light, and pedestrian walk signs
